fdd:description.p: WebM is an openly documented, non-proprietary, royalty-free open source format developed and maintained by Google and optimized for web-based media content. It was first announced on May 19, 2010 with wide industry support including Mozilla, Opera, Google Chrome and Adobe listed as collaborators. WebM is a subtype of the Matroska Multimedia Container which, in turn, is based on EBML. The DocType element in the EBML Header identifies the content of the EBML Body. For WebM, this would manifest as EBMLSchema docType="webm". See Matroska for details about the overall structure. As defined in the Implementation Details section of the WebM Container Guidelines, there are many elements not supported in WebM although are supported in Matroska. These include, for video 'ColourSpace', 'GammaValue', and for audio 'ChannelPositions', 'ContentCompression' (describing the compression used) and 'ContentCompAlgo ' (describing the compression algorithm used). Attachments are not supported by WebM.

fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: WebM is an openly documented, non-proprietary, royalty-free open source format developed and maintained by Google optimized for web-based media content.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:productionPhase: A final state format for enduser delivery.

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: The definition is via the same EBML schema used for Matroska.

fdd:relatedTo.fdd:titleName: VP8 Video Codec. Not described at this time

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: Developed by Google. Published as IETF RFC 6386 in 2011. Not defined as an Internet Standards Track specification but instead published for informational purposes only.

fdd:relatedTo.fdd:titleName: VP9 Video Codec. Not described at this time

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: Developed by Google. For more information, including link to specification published in in 2017, see Draft VP9 Bitstream and Decoding Process Specification

fdd:relatedTo.fdd:titleName: WebVTT (Web Video Text Tracks) Format. Not described at this time.

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: Standard format for subtitles, captions, and related timed metadata defined by WC3: WebVTT: The Web Video Text Tracks Format

fdd:localUse.fdd:experience: As of August 2020, the Library of Congress has over 2,300 files (6.6 GB) with the .webm extension in its digital collections. These have come from various sources, including archived websites.
fdd:localUse.fdd:preference: WebM is not included on the Recommended Formats Statement in relation to acquisition of digital video for LC collections.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:disclosure: WebM is an openly documented, non-proprietary, royalty-free open source format developed and maintained by Google in collaboration with the Alliance for Open Media. WebM is a constrained subtype of Matroska. Matroska is defined by EBML and the two are both standardized through the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF). As these are newer formats, all these specifications continue to evolve.

ul.li: The WebM specification is available on the WebM Project website
Matroska is an IETF Internet Draft specification. Draft version 05 is available as of this writing in August 2020
EBML format specification is standardized through IETF. https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-cellar-ebml/ is available as of this writing in August 2020.

fdd:adoption.p: The WebM Project lists a wide variety of tools for creating and publishing content in the WebM format including free and open source as well as commercial options. This includes FFmpeg, a popular open source "cross-platform solution to record, convert and stream audio and video" which has strong support for Matroska as well as FFV1. Other tools listed on the Matroska website include mkclean, a command line tool to clean and optimize Matroska and WebM files and mkvalidator a command line conformance checker for Matroska and WebM files. In addition, MKVToolNix is the de-facto reference implementation of a Matroska multiplexer which bundles a set of Matroska and WebM focused tools to get information about (via mkvinfo) Matroska files, extract tracks/data from (via mkvextract) Matroska files and create (via mkvmerge) Matroska files from other media files and (via) mkvpropedit can edit properties such as header and chapter information or attachments without remuxing.

Viewing options for WebM includes native support by Mozilla Firefox 4 and later, Opera 10.06 and later, Catalina, Sierra, and Google Chrome 6 and later while Internet Explorer 9+ requires the WebM for Internet Explorer plugin. According to Wikipedia, Safari for macOS which relied on QuickTime to play web media until Safari 12, still does not have native support for WebM. As of 2019 QuickTime does not natively support WebM, but does with a suitable third-party plug-in. In 2011, the Google WebM Project Team released plugins for Internet Explorer and Safari to allow playback of WebM files through the standard HTML5 video tag. Starting in June 2012, Internet Explorer 9 and later supported the WebM Media Foundation Components plugin for Windows Vista and later releases as well as Windows Media Player 12 on Windows 7 or 8. According to the WebM site, "although the components refer to Internet Explorer 9, installing them will add system-wide WebM support in applications that use Media Foundation." WebM provides DirectShow filters for playing and working with earlier versions. Comments welcome.
Other players with native support include VLC media player, MPlayer, K-Multimedia Player and JRiver Media Center.
WebM is supported on popular video sites including YouTube (a subsidiary of Google).

fdd:licensingAndPatents.p: WebM carries a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License from Google which states that "Google hereby grants to You a perpetual, worldwide, non-exclusive, no-charge, royalty-free, irrevocable (except as stated in this section) patent license to make, have made, use, offer to sell, sell, import, and otherwise transfer implementations of the WebM Specifications, where such license applies only to those patent claims, both currently owned by Google and acquired in the future, licensable by Google that are necessarily infringed by implementation of the WebM Specifications."
In addition, Google lists the Additional IP Rights Grant (Patents) for "the use of WebM codecs distributed by Google as part of the WebM Project."

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:transparency: Depends upon included encodings, some of which will depend upon algorithms and tools to read and require sophistication to build tools.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:techProtection: Encryption is supported in Matroska in a generic way "to allow people to implement whatever form of encryption is best for them" according to the IETF Internet draft from April 2020. In Matroska, encryption data is contained by the ContentEncryption element. According to WebM project, there is an effort to develop a more structured effort to support AES encryption through a W3C proposal (last updated August 2020 as of this writing). This project includes defining new elements specifically for Matroska and WebM including adding a master element named ContentEncAESSettings as a sub-element of the existing ContentEncryption element, which contains elements representing the features of AES. "ContentEncAESSettings contains one sub element. AESSettingsCipherMode conveys the block cipher mode used with the AES encryption. AESSettingsCipherMode contains one value, CTR. With these new elements, clients should be able to decode frames encoded with AES." In addition, WebM supports the existing Matroska elements: ContentEncryption, ContentEncAlgo, ContentEncKeyID, ContentEncAESSettings and AESSettingsCipherMode. Comments welcome.

fdd:internetMediaType.fdd:note: From WebM Container Guidelines. Not listed in IANA Media Type assignments as of August 2020. Comments welcome
For audio only content. From WebM Container Guidelines. Not listed in IANA Media Type assignments as of August 2020. Comments welcome

fdd:magicNumbers.fdd:note: From EBML specification, section 11.2.1. Used for all EBML-based files including Matroska Multimedia Container and WebM
"1A45DFA3{0-32}4282847765626D4287" from PRONOM fmt/573 entry. 0x1A45DFA3 ('EBML'), 0x428284 (EBML DocType element ID), 0x7765626D ('webm'), 0x4287 (EBML DocTypeVersion element ID)

fdd:values.fdd:note: As declared in the EBML Header

fdd:notes.fdd:general: YouTube's Michael Bradshaw included a presentation of WebM at the first No Time to Wait conference in Berlin in 2016. The blog post, A look into YouTube’s video file anatomy discusses WebM and Matroska's growing popularity. The YouTube Engineering and Developers blog in June 29, 2010 stated "we’re excited about the new WebM project. Google is open sourcing and contributing the VP8 codec to the WebM effort. Google, Mozilla, and Opera have all committed to support WebM, and we have already started making YouTube videos available in the WebM format. Adobe has also committed to support VP8, the video codec for WebM, in an upcoming Flash Player release.
